Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A Wastewater-Based-Epidemiology System for Early Detection of Viral Outbreaks in Detroit, MI

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Infectious disease outbreaks due to waterborne pathogens present a widespread health hazard, particularly in densely populated urban areas and among vulnerable populations. Viruses are among the most hazardous of these pathogens because of their ability to mutate and their high survivability in water and waste. Traditionally, disease detection and management has been accomplished through analysis of clinical samples from affected individuals who have sought medical treatment. Such detection may be slow, allowing an epidemic to emerge before effective public health measures can be taken. The objective of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to determine whether wastewater sampling for viral and other biomarkers provides effective prediction for water-related disease outbreaks. The research will provide the basis for a transformative new paradigm for early detection and prediction of disease outbreaks through smart monitoring of wastewater at a community level. This approach has the potential to be much faster than an approach based on clinical diagnostics alone, which is inherently limited to an after analysis of an outbreak. The project will provide opportunities for engineering students to develop research capabilities in addressing important public health issues

The research objective will be accomplished by integrating viral load and metabolic biomarker measurements from community wastewater samples with public health monitoring of disease. Data from a community wastewater treatment facility will be used to characterize the spatiotemporal distribution of viruses and other biomarkers within the sewer pipe network. Data from the county public health departments will be analyzed using epidemiological modeling to predict clinical cases of disease. These predictions, along with the high-dimensional raw data, will be used to create a nonlinear learning model to investigate the complex relationships among variables and to identify significant explanatory variables in order to improve the ability to predict disease outbreaks before they reach a critical stage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project is to develop a new paradigm for early detection, surveillance, and prediction of viral disease outbreaks in urban areas. The central premise of this work is that community wastewater represents a snapshot of the status of public health. Monitoring changes in virus concentration and diversity excreted in community wastewater, in combination with monitoring metabolites and biomarkers for population adjustment, allows early detection of outbreaks. In addition to waterborne viruses, the proposed approach is applicable to a wide range of viruses that are found in human excrement. Influent wastewater samples were collected from three sampling stations located within the Detroit Wastewater Treatment Plant between November 2017 and March 2019. Each station pulls raw sewage from one of three main interceptors: North Interceptor—East Arm (NI-EA), Detroit River (DRI), and Oakwood-Northwest-Wayne County (O-NWI). These interceptors collect sewage from most municipalities situated in the three largest counties in Michigan: Oakland, Wayne, and Macomb. The collected influent wastewater samples were analyzed for viruses and biomarkers. Viruses were concentrated from large volumes of wastewater using a virus adsorption-elution method. Viral RNA/DNA was extracted and samples were analyzed with molecular methods such as qPCR and shotgun sequencing. Furthermore, public health records for 2017-2019 were obtained from Michigan Department of Health and Human Services for comparison purposes. Weekly clinical data, expressed as number of viral disease cases per week per county, were extracted from disease surveillance reports, for Detroit City, Wayne, Oakland and Macomb counties. Laboratory analysis of wastewater samples indicates that strong associations exist between measured virus concentrations in wastewater and frequency of reported disease cases. Virome sequencing and metagenomic analysis results indicate high prevalence of multiple RNA and DNA viruses, such as hepatitis viruses, a wide variety of enteric viruses, multiple species of herpesviruses, HIV viruses, vector-borne viruses and others, in the Detroit area population. The detected viral sequences in wastewater samples correlated with reported public health records for related viral disease cases, confirming the association between detection of viruses in wastewater samples and observed clinical disease. Furthermore, selected viruses, such as Hepatitis A, were quantified using qPCR, and temporal and spatial variations were observed. Peaks in hepatitis A concentrations were related with peaks in reported hepatitis A clinical cases, during an outbreak that occurred in 2017-18. A viral outbreak early-detection model was created with inputs that include viral concentrations in wastewater, population estimations based on biomarker measurements, detention time estimations in the wastewater collection system, and clinical data, analyzed with biostatistics methods. The model was able to detect hepatitis A outbreaks two weeks prior to detection and report in clinical samples. Wastewater-based-epidemiology methods were proven effective for the identification of multiple RNA and DNA virus-related infections in the Detroit population. Furthermore, quantitative data demonstrated the ability of the method to provide early-signals of upcoming outbreaks.
